question.title: Lightweight Spring Boot Setup for Beginners: Zed editor
question.body:
I am new to Java and starting with Spring Boot development. I prefer using lightweight code editors like Zed, Lite-XL and Helix and want to avoid the high resource usage and complexity of full IDEs (Eclipse, IntelliJ).

The official Spring Tools are available for VS Code and Eclipse, which I am trying to bypass.

I am looking for advice on the best minimalist setup

  1. Zed : Is there a feasible way to achieve productive Spring Boot development (e.g., smart code completion, debugging) directly within a editor like Zed (Are there specific extensions, Language Server Protocol (LSP) configurations, or workarounds?)

  2. Minimalist IDE Alternative: If a full IDE is unavoidable, what is the most resource-light and quick-to-setup alternative for a Spring Boot project is neovim good or it ?, if yes how can i set it up i don't have good experience with vim but i can use helix

  3. Core Tooling: What are the essential command-line tools and scripts (Maven/Gradle commands) needed to run and manage a Spring Boot project entirely outside of an IDE?

Any tips for a new Java developer who values speed and a minimalist GUI workflow would be greatly appreciated!

answers.body:
Recommended IDEs and Tools for Spring Boot Beginners

For developers just starting with Spring Boot, the choice of an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) is crucial for a smooth learning experience.

I highly recommend the following IDEs, as they offer the best out-of-the-box support and require minimal setup for basic projects:

IDE

  • IntelliJ IDEA
    • Community Edition
    • https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/download
  • Eclipse
    • IDE for Enterprise Java and Web Developers
    • https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/release/2025-09/r
  • Spring Tool Suite (STS)
    • Spring Tools for Eclipse
    • https://spring.io/tools

Why Focus on These IDEs?

I strongly advise against using other IDEs when you are first learning Spring Boot. Here's why:

  • Avoid Configuration Headaches: If you notice that many people are frequently asking for basic configuration setup help for a particular IDE (like how to simply run or debug a fundamental project), it's a sign that the IDE is not easily intuitive for beginners.
  • Prioritize Learning, Not Troubleshooting: As a beginner, your time is best spent learning Spring Boot concepts, not wasting hours troubleshooting basic IDE configurations on a simple project. Stick to IntelliJ or Eclipse/STS to minimize setup friction.

Build Tool Recommendation

Regarding the build tool, both Maven and Gradle are excellent choices and fully supported by Spring Boot.

  • If you are unfamiliar with both, you can choose either one.
  • However, when working specifically with Spring Boot, I personally prefer using Maven.

Suggested Starting Point for Your Spring Boot Project Template

Please start by using Spring Initializr (https://start.spring.io/).

This tool will help you generate the initial project structure and dependencies.

There are multiple options below; the one marked with (*) indicates the option I personally prefer to use under normal circumstances.

  • Project

    • Gradle - Groovy
    • Gradle - Kotlin
    • Maven(*)

  • Language

    • Java (*)
    • Kotlin
    • Groovy

  • Spring Boot

    • 4.0.1 (SNAPSHOT)
    • 4.0.0
    • 3.5.9 (SNAPSHOT)
    • 3.5.8 (*)
    • 3.4.13 (SNAPSHOT)
    • 3.4.12

  • Project Metadata

    • Group: com.example
    • Artifact: demo
    • Name: demo
    • Description: Demo project for Spring Boot
    • Package name: com.example.demo

  • Packaging

    • Jar (*)
    • War

  • Configuration

    • Properties (*)
    • YAML

  • Java

    • 25
    • 21
    • 17 (*)

Common Maven Commands for Spring Boot

build

mvn clean package

run

java -jar target/app.jar

Docs

  • spring-boot tutorial

    • https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/3.5/tutorial/index.html

  • How-to Guides

    • https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/3.5/how-to/index.html
@life888888: IntelliJ IDEA Community Edition does not support Spring Boot, not even "classic" Spring. See https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/features/. This is a feature of the paid Ultimate Edition.

@cyberbrain: (1) I don't understand what you mean by 'IntelliJ IDEA Community Edition does not support Spring Boot.' (2) My standard workflow is to generate a Maven project using Spring Initializr (https://start.spring.io/) and download the resulting ZIP file. (3) After unzipping the file, I open the project directory in IntelliJ IDEA Community Edition as a Maven project. (4) Once the Spring Boot Maven project is open, I can execute the Spring Boot Application directly within the Community Edition by simply opening the XXXXApplication.java file and clicking 'Run'."

@life88888 This probably means that the IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate Edition offers many more additional features for working with Spring, such as Spring Debugger, showing endpoints, etc.

But for starters, the Community Edition and the method you described should be perfectly adequate.

https://www.jetbrains.com/products/compare/?product=idea&product=idea-ce
Thanks for such a brief answer appreciated !
